Expectation1: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation1: The experiment is reserved during a limited window when specialized instruments are available.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: An upcoming holiday is near, and the children still need to learn the related blessings.
Story: I stared at the lab schedule, my name highlighted in yellow for the only available slot to use the spectrometer this month. The experiment was crucial—months of preparation, grant money on the line, and my team counting on me to gather the data. But as I scrolled through my calendar, my heart sank. The slot overlapped with the days leading up to Shavuot. My children were waiting for me at home, their eager faces expecting stories of Ruth and lessons on the Ten Commandments. I had promised to teach them the blessings, to bake challah together, to pass on the traditions my parents gave me. My colleagues expected precision and dedication; my family expected presence and guidance. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, the sterile hum of the lab echoing in my mind as I pictured my children’s hopeful eyes. I sat at my desk, torn, the demands of science and faith pulling me in opposite directions, unsure which part of myself I would have to disappoint.
